awd_titl_txt: Conference: Broadening Access to Research Opportunities in South Central EPSCoR States
awd_abstract_narration:
This project supports holding a conference that will broaden the reach of NSF-funded research across five states located in the south-central region of the United States that have historically received less than average NSF funding.  Principal Investigators (PIs) from different types of institutions across the states of Kansas, Oklahoma, Arkansas, Louisiana, and Mississippi will be invited to participate and will be given the opportunity to gain new knowledge on how to develop well-designed research projects and craft strong research proposals that will enhance their competitiveness in securing NSF grants.  NSF officers representing the four different clusters within the Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences (MCB) will also attend the conference and will provide information on the different types of funding opportunities available at the NSF and insights into the grant proposal application process.

The conference will be held at Hendrix College, a small liberal arts college and predominantly undergraduate institution (PUI) located in Conway, Arkansas.  Invitations will be extended to PIs from other PUIs as well as Minority-Serving Institutions (MSIs), Historically Black Colleges and Universities (HBCUs), and Research Institutions (R1s, R2s).  A particular focus will be placed on ensuring strong representation of women investigators and investigators from groups historically under-represented in STEM.  During the conference, participants will have ample opportunities to interact with each other and will be encouraged to explore possible collaborations that could enhance cross-institutional connections and lead to stronger grant proposal applications.  The overall impact of the conference will be quite extensive as it will not only directly benefit the participants, but it will be further amplified as PIs will likely share their newly acquired knowledge with colleagues at their home institutions and beyond.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The major goal of the Broadening Access to Research Opportunities in South Central EPSCoR States conference held at Hendrix College on November 3-4, 2023 was to broaden the scope of NSF-funded research across the United States by providing researchers across five states in the south central region (Arkansas, Kansas, Louisiana, Oklahoma, and Mississippi) with information on the various funding opportunities available at the NSF (mostly within the Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences) and on how to design and write competitive grant applications.  Another goal for this conference was to provide researchers with an opportunity to meet each other and to develop cross-institutional research collaborations that could form the basis for strong research plans and future grant applications.  The conference was attended by sixty researchers across the five target states as well as by five NSF Program Directors who delivered presentations addressing key aspects of the NSF funding process and held informational sessions with the researchers. 

Both formal and informal feedback from conference participants demonstrated that the conference was overall very effective.  Results from an online post-event survey and informal conversations during and after the conference indicated that researchers particularly appreciated the opportunities to meet NSF Program Directors, to discuss various aspects of grant proposals, to meet with other researchers from the region, and to learn more about NSF funding opportunities and how to write strong proposals.  Many participants also indicated that following the conference they were considering applying for NSF grants and that the conference sparked ideas for possible future collaborations within their area of research.  This very positive feedback confirms that the conference successfully met its primary goals of providing participants with tools to enable them to prepare competitive NSF grant applications and to stimulate research collaborations across the south central region of the United States.

 


Last Modified: 12/09/2024
Modified by: Andrea A Duina
